'''[[Human rights]] in [[Timeline of the 2011 Egyptian revolution under Supreme Council of the Armed Forces|Post-Mubarak transition]]''' have been the subject of concerns and controversies since the [[2011 Egyptian revolution]]. The '''[[Supreme Council of the Armed Forces]] (SCAF) ({{lang-ar|Ø§ÙÙØ¬ÙØ³ Ø§ÙØ£Ø¹ÙÙ ÙÙÙÙØ§Øª Ø§ÙÙØ³ÙØ­Ø©}}, ''{{transl|ar|DIN|al-MaÇ§lis al-Ê¾AÊ¿lÄ lil-QuwwÄt al-Musallaá¸¥ah}}'' have been accused of [[Human rights in Egypt|human rights]] [[Human rights violations|violations]]''' in [[Egypt]] after the ouster of [[President of Egypt|President]] [[Hosni Mubarak]] on February 11, 2011<ref name=globe>{{cite news |url=http://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/world/crisis-in-egypt/the-new-face-of-power-in-cairo/article1904700/ |author=The Globe and Mail |title=The New Face of Power in Egypt. |date=February 11, 2011| accessdate=February 11, 2011}}</ref><ref name=wt>{{cite news| url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2011/feb/11/crowds-rejoice-egypts-mubarak-steps-down/ |author=Murdock, Heather |title=Crowds rejoice as Egyptâs Mubarak steps down, hands power to military| publisher=[[The Washington Times]]| date=February 11, 2011| accessdate=February 11, 2011}}</ref> as a consequence of the [[2011 Egyptian revolution]].
+
'''[[Human rights]] in [[Timeline of the 2011 Egyptian revolution under Supreme Council of the Armed Forces|Post-Mubarak transition]]''' have been the subject of concerns and controversies since the [[2011 Egyptian revolution]]. The '''[[Supreme Council of the Armed Forces]] (SCAF)''' ({{lang-ar|Ø§ÙÙØ¬ÙØ³ Ø§ÙØ£Ø¹ÙÙ ÙÙÙÙØ§Øª Ø§ÙÙØ³ÙØ­Ø©}}, ''{{transl|ar|DIN|al-MaÇ§lis al-Ê¾AÊ¿lÄ lil-QuwwÄt al-Musallaá¸¥ah}}''have been accused of [[Human rights in Egypt|human rights]] [[Human rights violations|violations]]. The SCAF, which consists of a body of 20<ref name=sis>{{cite web| url=http://www.sis.gov.eg/En/LastPage.aspx?Category_ID=1136| author=Egypt State Information Service| title=Formation of the Armed Forces Supreme Council.| date=February 14, 2011}} Archived at webcite at http://www.webcitation.org/5wTMNq7Mb</ref> senior officers in the [[Egyptian Armed Forces|Egyptian military]], was handed the power to govern [[Egypt]] after the ouster of [[President of Egypt|President]] [[Hosni Mubarak]] on February 11, 2011<ref name=globe>{{cite news |url=http://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/world/crisis-in-egypt/the-new-face-of-power-in-cairo/article1904700/ |author=The Globe and Mail |title=The New Face of Power in Egypt. |date=February 11, 2011| accessdate=February 11, 2011}}</ref><ref name=wt>{{cite news| url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2011/feb/11/crowds-rejoice-egypts-mubarak-steps-down/ |author=Murdock, Heather |title=Crowds rejoice as Egyptâs Mubarak steps down, hands power to military| publisher=[[The Washington Times]]| date=February 11, 2011| accessdate=February 11, 2011}}</ref> as a consequence of the 2011 Egyptian revolution.
